data.title: Dujardin plays love-struck Russian spy in Luxembourg co-production
data.meta_description: French actor Jean Dujardin plays a Russian spy in his latest film, MÖBIUS, but things get complicated as he gets entangled in a web of lies and love.
data.text:
(CS) French actor Jean Dujardin plays a Russian spy in his latest film, MÖBIUS, but things get complicated as he gets entangled in a web of lies and love.

Co-produced by Luxembourg production company Samsa Film, the film by French director Eric Rochant is billed as a spy thriller, but it is love story which stands at the heart of the film - a story of forbidden love to be precise, as Russian spy Grégory Lioubov, alias Moïse, starts a passionate affair with Cécile de France's Alice, the woman he is following.

But Alice, too, is more than she seems. The finance genius is on a mission of her own, and double agents abounds as spies are spied on, and hunters become the hunted.

Tim Roth's villainous Rostovsky is the glue that holds the various storylines together...but then again, the CIA also has a stake in the game.

Cécile de France offers emotional performance

At a press conference for the first screening of MÖBIUS in Luxembourg on February 28, director Eric Rochant explained that the spy genre offered the perfect backdrop for the story he wanted to tell about tensions, power, influence and a world of lies, giving a larger focus to a traditional love drama.

Shot on 35mm film rather than digital format, the film's look is deliberately more grainy and intimate, highlighting the sensual aspects of the film, Rochant said.

While Dujardin was the first choice for the film, it is Cécile de France who offers a particularly emotional performance, treading on thin ice as she finds herself out of her depth in a web of international espionage, and looking for protection from a man not in a position to make promises.

Despite the international character of the film, English-speaking audiences should take note that large parts of the film's action are in French, with some English and Russian, which is subtitled in French in Luxembourg. With a relatively complicated plot, only those who have mastered the French language to a more advanced degree should dare to enter the world of MÖBIUS.
